response.answer_text: Next great evolution for technology? As in; the best invention since sliced bread? So far we've had the wheel, electricity/light bulb, aeroplanes, sliced bread, internet. (this isn't really a serious list. Just some stuff to give you an idea of what we're paying with). I propose; “the driverless car" Yes, yes. I know this has already been invented, and is successfully in use. But I'm talking about using it to its full potential. Imagine ONE company, that acts like a taxi company. That owns 100% of all vehicles on the road. And all these vehicles were exactly the same make and model, driverless car. (exceptions for the trucks, ambulance, special service vehicles). Imagine you, the customer; Not buying a car Not buying insurance Not buying petrol Not paying for parking Not paying for any fines Not paying for rego Not paying for a new set of tyres Not paying for a mechanic Not risking your life or the lives of others because of human error. Making it to work in half the time because there are no more traffic lights, and all cars can communicate with each other, allowing for higher, safer speeds, and no need to slow down because of dense traffic. And how much will the consumer pay? Less (way less) than it would for the consumer to buy a cheap car, and keep it on the road. How can it be cheaper? The ONE company can cut costs by; having only one type of vehicle to supply parts to. No costs for insurance. Rarely any damage to cars. Buy in bulk car parts, fuel (petrol or electric. If electric, the company can set up it's own solar plant) Other benefits include; No “hoons” or illegal street racing Less death on roads. (much less. Almost 0%) More time saved by commuters. Ability to work whilst traveling (these cars will have Wi-Fi) Can assist emergency vehicles by blocking off wrong streets, and effectively avoiding the route of the emergency vehicle entirely. Can be used as an emergency vehicle if applicable. …. This can revolutionise the way we travel. So convenient. So safe. So cheap. I'd love to make this my business, but I don't have the funds. And I'm in the wrong country (Australia)

Ask this question to various experts and you are likely to get a deluge of varying responses, from full migration of data to cloud-based solutions to breakthroughs in genetic research that will allow us to live longer and stronger. But if i were to pick one piece of technology that is affecting our world more than any other, and at a faster rate, i would have to pick the evolution of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning. As AI’s evolve and become more complete they bring with them the ability to handle a more complex and larger volume of work. This means that other technologies that make use of it such as self-driving cars, data visualization and a host of others will see quantitative leaps in their development also. Autonomous artificial intelligence (AI) is fueling a new era of people and machines working together with data-driven insights and highly strategic and outcome-focused processes. To fully realize the promise of the AI-fueled organization, we can highlight three system models currently in play: cloud-native, package-adjunct, and open-algorithm. By embracing AI, machine learning (ML), and other cognitive tools across the IT ecosystem, we can spend less time on redundant and mundane activities that waste the value of every employee and spend more time on informed decision-making. But the enterprise is not the only space AI is going to make its mark, In June 2018, researchers at OpenAI developed a technique that trains an AI on unlabeled text to avoid the expense and time of categorizing and tagging all the data manually. A few months later, a team at Google unveiled a system called BERT that learned how to predict missing words by studying millions of sentences. In a multiple-choice test, it did as well as humans at filling in gaps. And as we progress this technology is already evolving into full competent assistants that can allow us to navigate our business and personal lives.

I’m writing from the perspective of gen z, but some of this may apply to millenials as well. Space expansion. Super intelligent AI. Immortality. Perhaps even the technological singularity. Michio Kaku, a theoretical physicist and futurist, wrote about the future of humanity in his latest book, The Future of Humanity. He prophecises that humans will terraform mars and start expanding into space. He also covered things like nuclear fusion and solar sails. These technologies will aid humanity’s journey into the final frontier, and this will be the defining tech challenges for this generation. Max Tegmark’s book, Life 3.0, talks about what it would mean to be human in the future. In particular, he spends a large amount of the book talking about the technological superintellegence. Nick Bostrom wrote a book dedicated to the subject, but I got to page 12 and gave up (it’s very technical, I’ll pick it up again after I take AP calculus). Basically the idea is that the superintellegence is an AI that is more intelligent than a human. A big challenge for our generation is to figure out what this means, and what do we do with it, if we want it at all. While not heavily covered, Kaku’s book (the one mentioned above) spends a short chapter discussing the potential for immortality. Your genes start to weaken and start breaking down as you progress into old age, but scientists have found a specific part of DNA that stops this; tests in mice have increased lifespan. They’re called telomeres, and altering them could potentially stop aging, perhaps making you immortal. By immortal, I mean stop aging, but if you get hit by a train, you’re still probably going to die. An End to Aging: Can Science Allow Humans to To Become Immortal? Finally: the technological singularity. This is the hypothesis that one day a self replicating AI would create a new “generation” of itself a little bit smarter. That generation would create the next generation and so on, until it got so smart that a new generation is made constantly and intelligence increases at an exponential rate. Whether this will happen or not is up to debate, and so is when it will happen. But no matter the fate of this idea, it is still an interesting possibility to explore.
